    <p style="text-align:justify"><strong>What is Debenture?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Debenture is a financial instrument which does not carry any voting rights in a company and is a part of borrowed capital used by corporate entities for raising long term debt capital and can issued through Public issue or Private Placement. A debenture in a company is a movable property and transferable in nature. A Debenture holder is a creditor of the company and a fixed rate of interest is paid on debenture. Debenture primarily is of two types i.e. Convertible Debenture and Non-Convertible Debenture.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Debenture as defined by the Section 2(30) of the Companies Act, 2013 means and includes debenture stock, bonds or any other instrument of a company evidencing a debt, whether constituting a charge on the assets of the company or not, however, instruments referred to in Chapter III-D of the Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 and; such other instrument, as may be prescribed by the Central Government in consultation with the Reserve Bank of India , issued by a Company, shall not be treated as debenture.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>What are Non-Convertible Debentures?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Non-Convertible Debentures (NCDs) are a type of Debenture that are not converted into the Equity Shares of the issuer Company but are instead, redeemed i.e. the principal amount along with the interest is repaid to the investor on the fixed maturity date.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">NCDs give a high rate of return to the investors as compared to the convertible debentures the reason being that the NCDs are pure debt instrument and the investors do not get any ownership of the Company pursuant to conversion. NCDs allow the investors to earn high rate of interest on their investment and in turn allow the promoters or founders & the other shareholders to maintain their stake in the Company without worrying about the dilution.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Further, listed NCDs can be transferred which makes it a liquid investment whereby the investor can transfer his investment to other person and get his investment return without waiting till the maturity period. However, such transfer shall be subject to the conditions of the issue.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">NCDs can be secured as well as unsecured, however, unsecured NCDs issued by an unlisted entity are considered as Deposits under the provisions of the Companies Act, 2013 and compliance with respect to Deposits is also required to be followed by such unlisted entities. </p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Requirements/ Conditions for issue of NCDs:</strong></p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		NCDs can be issued only <strong>with the redemption date not exceeding 10 (Ten) years.</strong><br>
		However, (i) Companies engaged in setting up infrastructure projects; (ii) Infrastructure Finance Companies as defined in Non-Banking Financial (Non-Deposit Accepting or Holding) Companies Prudential Norms (Reserve Bank) Directions, 2007; (iii) Infrastructure Debt Fund Non-Banking Financial Companies as defined in Infrastructure Debt Fund Non-Banking Financial Companies (Reserve Bank) Directions, 2011; and (iv) Companies permitted by a Ministry or Department of the Central Government or by Reserve Bank of India or by the National Housing Bank or by any other statutory authority to issue debentures  can issue NCDs <strong>with the redemption date exceeding 10 (Ten) years but not exceeding 30 (Thirty) years.</strong>
	</li>
	
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Section 71(5) of the Companies Act, 2013 states that a Company should appoint one or more Debenture Trustee(s) before issuing a prospectus or letter of offer for subscription of NCDs, and not later than 60 (Sixty) days after the allotment of NCDs to execute a Debenture Trust Deed in Form No. SH-12 with the Debenture Trustee to protect the interests of the NCDs holder and redress their grievances. Manner of appointment of the Debenture Trustee and duties of the Debenture Trustee shall be as specified in Rule 18 of the Companies (Share Capital and Debentures) Rules, 2014.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Issue of Secured NCDs shall be secured by the creation of a charge in favour of the Debenture Trustee on the property or assets of the Company or its subsidiaries or its holding company or its associate companies, having a value of which is sufficient for the redemption of Debentures and interest thereon.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		On issuance of debentures by the Company, the Company shall create a Debenture Redemption Reserve (DRR) out of the profits of the Company available for the payment of dividend. The limits of adequacy of DRR shall be as under:
		
		<p>
			<u>Exemptions are granted from creation of DRR to the following Companies issuing debentures:</u>
		</p>
		
		<ol type="i">
			<li style="text-align:justify">
				All India Financial Institutions regulated by the Reserve Bank of India and Banking Companies for both public as well as privately placed debentures;
			</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">
				Listed Entities (other than All India Financial Institutions and Banking Companies as specified above) including NBFCs registered with the Reserve Bank of India under Section 45-IA of the RBI Act, 1934 and the Housing Finance Companies registered with the National Housing Bank, for both public as well as privately placed debentures;
			</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">
				Unlisted NBFCs registered with the Reserve Bank of India under Section 45-IA of the RBI Act, 1934 and the Housing Finance Companies registered with the National Housing Bank, for privately placed debentures.
			</li>
		</ol>

			<p><u>Limit of adequacy of DRR:</u></p>
			<p style="text-align:justify">For other unlisted entities (other than All India Financial Institutions and Banking Companies as specified above), the adequacy of DRR shall be 10% of the value of outstanding debentures.</p>
			<p style="text-align:justify">
				Further, (i) Listed Entities (other than All India Financial Institutions and Banking Companies as specified above) including NBFCs registered with the Reserve Bank of India under Section 45-IA of the RBI Act, 1934 and the Housing Finance Companies registered with the National Housing Bank; and (ii) other unlisted entities shall on or before 30th April in each year, in respect of debentures issued by them, invest or deposit, as the case may be, a sum not less than 15% of the amount of debentures maturing during the year ending on the 31st March of the next year in any one or more of the following methods of investments or deposits:
			</p>	
			<ol type="a">
				<li style="text-align:justify">in deposits with any Scheduled Bank, free</li>
				<li style="text-align:justify">in unencumbered securities from any charge or lien of the Central or the State Governments</li>
				<li style="text-align:justify">in unencumbered bonds issued by any other company which is notified under Section 20(f) of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882</li>
				<li style="text-align:justify">in unencumbered bonds securities mentioned in sub-clause (a) to (d) and (ee) of the Section 20  of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882</li>
			</ol>
			<p style="text-align:justify">Any such amount created as DRR or invested or deposited as stated above shall not be utilized for any purpose other than redemption of debentures.</p>
		</li>
			
		<li style="text-align:justify">
			Repayment of principal and interest amount shall be made in accordance with the terms of issue of NCDs.
		</li>
	</ul>


<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Consequences of non-repayment of principal or interest amount of debentures:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Any time during the currency of the NCDs, the Debentures Trustee concludes that the assets of the Company are insufficient or like to become insufficient to discharge the principal amount as and when it becomes due, he may file a petition before the Tribunal and the Tribunal may, after hearing the matter, pass an order imposing restrictions on the incurring of any further liabilities by the Company as the Tribunal consider necessary in the interests of the NCD holders.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">If the Company fails to redeem the NCDs on the date of maturity or fails to pay interest on the NCDs when it is due, the Tribunal may, on the application of any or all the NCDs holders or Debenture Trustee and after hearing the concerned parties pass an order directing the Company to redeem the NCDs forthwith on payment of principal and interest due thereon.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">If any default is made in complying with the order passed by the Tribunal, every officer of the Company who is in default shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 3 (Three) years or with fine which shall not less than INR 2 (Two) lakhs but which may extend to INR 5 (Five) lakhs, or with both.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Provisions of SEBI Regulations with respect to the issue of NCDs:</strong></p>
<ol type="1">
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Credit rating including the unaccepted ratings obtained from more than one credit rating agencies, registered with SEBI shall be disclosed in the offer document for issue of NCDs.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		The issuer cannot issue NCDs for providing loan to or for acquisition of shares of any person who is part of the same group or who is under the same management.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Listed entities having issued NCDs, shall not declare or distribute any dividend wherein it has defaulted in payment of interest on any debt securities or redemption thereof or in creation of security as per the terms of the issue of any debt securities.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Listed entities shall not forfeit unclaimed interest and such unclaimed interest shall be transferred to the ‘Investor Education and Protection Fund’ set up as per Section 125 of the Companies Act, 2013.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any listed entity issuing NCDs shall, in addition to the requirements/ conditions specified under the Companies Act, 2013, also comply with the provisions of the SEBI (Issue and Listing of Debt Securities) Regulations, 2008 with respect to the issue and listing of NCDs and; with the disclosure requirements laid down in the SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015.
	</li>	
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Tax on NCDs:</strong></p>
<ol type="1">
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		If sold on the exchange before maturity within one year: Short-Term Capital Gains Tax at applicable rates depending on the tax bracket/ slab of the investor.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		If sold on the exchange before maturity but after one year: Long-Term Capital Gains Tax at the at the applicable rates with or without indexation benefits.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		If held till Maturity: Interest earned is added to the total income & taxed at marginal rate of income tax depending on the tax bracket/ slab of the investor.
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Tax benefit to company issuing NCDs: Interest payment on NCDs is a deductible expense for the company.
	</li>	
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Loan against NCDs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Banks and financial institutions fulfill the monetary requirements of every individual as per their credit worthiness and paying capacity. One step in this direction has been Loan against Securities, popularly referred to as LAS. Under “Loan against Securities”, loan is advanced to a customer against pledge of securities or simply put loan against insurance policy, mutual funds, NSC and other securities. The list of approved securities against which LAS can be advanced varies from bank to bank and NCDs. is one of the securities considered to be approved securities against which LAS could be given.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Conclusion:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">NCDs look attractive to investors because of the fixed and sizeable income investment and being a traditional investment but if the Company fails to repay the returns as per their plans due to liquidity issues or poor performance, then the investor is at the risk of losing his complete investment amount. The investor shall before investing in the NCDs, consider the rating of the NCDs (in case of listed entities) and the fundamentals & liquidity of the Company. Also, tax is charged on the interest earned from NCDs at the slab rate in which the investor falls in which means that if the investor falls in the top tax slab then his interest income will be charged at the top tax bracket, so the investment decision also has to be made considering the tax impact.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">For a Company issuing NCDs, it may seem good option considering NCDs protect the promoters/ founders and other shareholder from dilution of their existing stake and getting a debt investment at a more or less similar interest rates as compared to loans from banking and other financial institutions but if the repayment capacity or liquidity is the issue for the Company then the Company should not issue NCDs and should go for some option of raising funds through equity, as non-repayment or contravention of terms of issue of NCDs results in penalties and also downgrading of the Company’s credit rating which can affect its future operations & fund raising capabilities.</p>

    <p style="text-align:justify">In simple words Related Party Transactions (RPTs) are those transactions that a Company does with the parties related to it directly or indirectly through its Promoters, Directors, Key Managerial Persons and, Relatives of Promoters, Directors and Key Managerial Persons. However, RPTs are usually not simple but the most complicated and sensitive transactions from the point of view of the Company’s operations & its corporate governance. RPTs are generally the crux of any fraud/misdoings happening inside the Company.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Various provisions have been enacted under various act/ regulations to address the issue related to the misdoings happening due to RPTs and to regulate the RPTs by putting restrictions, conditions of pre-approval, pre & post transaction disclosures/ compliances, etc. A brief overview of RPTs and provisions related to it are being covered herein.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Who is a Related Party?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">As per the provisions of the Section 2(76) of the Companies Act, 2013 (“the Act”) and Rule 3 of Companies (Specification of definitions details) Rules, 2014, a Related Party, with reference to a company means the following:</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A Director, KMP or any of their relatives;
	</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A Firm, or Private Limited Company in which a Director, Manager or his relative is a partner, member or director;
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A public company in which a Director or Manager is a Director and holds along with his relatives, more than two per cent of its paid-up share capital;
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate whose Board of Directors, Managing Director or Manager is accustomed to act in accordance with the advice, directions or instructions of a Director or Manager (excluding advice, directions or instructions given in a professional capacity);
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any person on whose advice, directions or instructions a Director or Manager is accustomed to act (excluding advice, directions or instructions given in a professional capacity);
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		A Director other than an Independent Director or KMP of the holding company or any of his relatives (shall be deemed to be a related party)
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate which is a Holding, Subsidiary or Associate Company of such Company
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate which is a Sister concern i.e. a subsidiary company of a holding company to which it is also a subsidiary
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any Body Corporate which is an Investing Company or Venturer Company (which means a body corporate whose investment in the company would result in the company becoming an associate company of the body corporate)
		<p>
			In addition to the above persons, following shall also be deemed to be a Related Party as per the SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015, applicable only for Listed Entities:
		</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Any person or entity belonging to the promoter or promoter group of the listed entity and holding 20% or more shareholding in the listed entity
	</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<em>[Point Nos. (vii), (viii) & (ix) above are not applicable to a Private Limited Company]</em>
</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">Further, a Relative with reference to any person, means anyone who is related to another, if:</p>
<ol type="i">
<li style="text-align:justify">they are members of a Hindu Undivided Family;</li> 
<li style="text-align:justify">they are husband and wife; or</li>
<li style="text-align:justify">one person is related to the other in the manner mentioned below:</li>
	<ol type="a">
		<li style="text-align:justify">Father (including step-father)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Mother (including step-mother)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Son (including step-son)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Son’s wife</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Daughter</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Daughter’s husband</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Brother (including step-brother)</li>
		<li style="text-align:justify">Sister (including step-sister)</li>
	</ol>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Transactions considered as RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">
	RPTs are not prohibited but prior consent of the Board of Directors is required for all RPTs (including approval of Audit Committee in case of Listed Entities and those entities who are required to constitute an Audit Committee). Further consent of shareholders is also required for RPTs exceeding the thresholds prescribed for each such RPT in Section 188 of the Act and Rule 15 of the Companies (Meetings of Board and its Powers) Rules, 2014.
</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">
	Following are the transactions which are considered as Related Party Transactions:
</p>

<table width="100%" border="1" cellspacing="0" class="MsoTableGrid" style="border-collapse:collapse; border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;">
	<tbody>		
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top"><strong>Related Party Transactions (requiring prior consent of Board of Directors)</strong></td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top"><strong>Thresholds which if exceeded require approval of shareholders of the Company</strong></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">a. Sale/ Purchase/ Supply of any goods or materials</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Sale/ Purchase/ Supply of any goods or materials directly or through appointment of an agent <b>amounting to 10% or more of the turnover of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">b. Selling/ otherwise Disposing/ Buying property of any kind</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Selling/ otherwise Disposing/ Buying property of any kind directly or through appointment of an agent <b>amounting to 10% or more of the networth of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">c. Leasing of property of any kind</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Leasing of property of any kind <b>amounting to 10% or more of the turnover of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">d. Availing/ Rendering of any services</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Availing/ Rendering of any services directly or through appointment of an agent <b>amounting to 10% or more of the turnover of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">e. Appointing of any agent for any of the above purposes</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Thresholds covered in point nos. a, b & d above.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">f. Such related party's appointment to any office or place of profit in the company, its subsidiary company or associate company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Such related party's appointment to any office or place of profit in the company, its subsidiary company or associate company is at <b>a monthly remuneration exceeding Rupees Two Lakhs Fifty Thousand</b></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">g. Underwriting the subscription of any securities or derivatives thereof, of the company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Underwriting the subscription of any securities or derivatives thereof, of the company <b>exceeding 1% of the networth of the company</b></td>
		</tr>
	</tbody>
</table>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<em>
		[Note:<br>
		1. Thresholds specified in point nos. a to d above shall apply for transaction(s) to be entered into either individually or taken together with the previous transactions during a financial year.<br>
		2. Turnover or Networth referred to in above threshold limits shall be computed on the basis of the Audited Financial Statements of the preceding Financial Year.]
	</em>
</p>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<strong>General Conditions/ Requirements & exemptions for RPTs:</strong>
</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">No approval (either of Board of Directors or Shareholders of the Company) is required for transactions entered into by the Company in its ordinary course of business and which are at arm’s length price.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">No approval of Board of Directors required for RPTs entered into between a Holding Company and its Wholly Owned Subsidiary whose accounts are consolidated with such Holding Company and placed before the shareholders at the general meeting for approval.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Any member who is a related party shall not vote on the transaction for which he is a related party. However, the same shall not be applicable to a Private Limited Company and a Company in which 90% or more members (in numbers) are relatives of promoters or are related parties. </li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Any Director who is interested in any contract/ arrangement/ transaction (as specified in the Section 184 of the Act) shall not participate in the Board Meeting where such contract/ arrangement/ transaction is discussed. However, in case of a Private Limited Company, such a Director may participate in the discussion after giving disclosure of his interest in the said contract/ arrangement/ transaction.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">In case the contract or arrangement is entered into by a Director/ any other employee without prior consent of Board or the members of the company and is subsequently not ratified by the Board of Directors or the shareholders of the Company, as the case may be, within 3 months of from the date on which such transaction is entered, such transaction shall be voidable at the option of Board or members, as the case may be and if the contract or arrangement is with a Related Party to any Director, or is authorised by any other Director, the Directors concerned shall indemnify the Company against any loss incurred by it.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">The Company can proceed against a Director or any employee who had entered into a contract/ arrangement in contravention of the provisions of the Act for recovery of any loss sustained by it as a result of such contract/ arrangement.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<strong>Compliances for RPTs:</strong>
</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Agenda of the Board Meeting & explanatory statement annexed with the notice of general meeting of the Company shall disclose the details such as name of Related Party, nature of relationship with the Related Party, duration of contract/ arrangement, material terms of the contract/ arrangement including the value, if any and any other information relevant for the Directors or the Shareholders of the Company to take decision on the proposed transaction.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">Details of every RPT must be reported in the Annual Board’s Report to the Shareholders along with justification for entering into RPTs.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">All Directors shall provide disclosure of their interests in other companies/ concerns/ firms in Form MBP-1 every year in the first Board Meeting he attends and whenever there is a change in his interests previously disclosed by him.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">Company shall maintain a Register in Form MBP-4 for entering particulars of RPTs.</li> 
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">
	<strong>Role of Audit Committee in RPTs:</strong>
</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">In case of Listed Entities and Companies who are required to constitute an Audit Committee, Audit Committee plays a vital role in approval and subsequent modifications of RPTs. All RPTs shall require approval of the Audit Committee and the Audit Committee may make Omnibus approval for RPTs proposed to be entered into by the Company subject to certain conditions specified in the Act:</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Audit Committee shall consider repetitiveness of the transactions (in past or in future) and justification for the need of omnibus approval while specifying criteria for making omnibus approval. </li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Omnibus approval shall contain all such necessary information with respect to the transaction. However, where the need of RPT cannot be foreseen and details of RPT are not available, Audit Committee may make Omnibus approval for such transactions for an amount not exceeding INR 1,00,00,000 (Rupees One Crore) per transaction.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Omnibus approval shall be valid for one financial year only and fresh approval shall be required after the expiry of such financial year. It shall not be applicable for transactions of selling and disposing of the undertaking of the company.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Penalty for contravention of provisions of the Act in case of RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">
	Any Director/ any other employee who had entered into the contract/ arrangement with the Related Party in contravention of the provision of the Act, shall be liable to the following penalty:
</p>

<table width="100%" border="1" cellspacing="0" class="MsoTableGrid" style="border-collapse:collapse; border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;">
	<tbody>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">In case of Listed Company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">
				Imprisonment maximum up to one year; or<br>
				Fine not less than INR 25,000 maximum up to INR 5,00,000; or<br>
				Both with Imprisonment and Fine
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">In case of any other Company</td>
			<td style="vertical-align:top">Fine not less than INR 25,000 maximum up to INR 5,00,000</td>
		</tr>		
	</tbody>
</table>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Provisions of SEBI LODR Regulations related to RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Listed Entities shall be additionally required to comply with the following provisions of Securities and Exchange Board of India (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Requirements) Regulations, 2015 with respect to RPTs:</p>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Related Party Transaction means a transfer of resources, services or obligations between a listed entity and a Related Party, regardless of whether a price is charged and a transaction with a Related Party shall be construed to include a single transaction or a group of transactions in a contract.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Listed entities shall formulate a policy on materiality of RPTs and on dealing with the same (including clear threshold limits duly approved by the Board of Directors and such policy shall be reviewed by the Board of Directors at least once every 3 (Three) years & update accordingly) and publish the same on the website of the company. 
		<p>
			Material transaction shall mean transaction to be entered into individually or taken together with previous transactions during a financial year, exceeds 10% of the annual consolidated turnover of the listed entity as per the last audited financial statements.
		</p>
		<p>
			However, a transaction involving payments to related party with respect to brand usage or royalty shall be considered material if the transactions individually or taken together with previous transactions during a financial year, exceeds 5% of the annual consolidated turnover of the listed entity as per the last audited financial statements.
		</p>
	</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">All material RPTs shall require approval of the shareholders by way of passing an Ordinary Resolution and no Related Party shall approve such resolutions irrespective of whether the entity is a Related Party to the particular transaction or not.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">The listed entity shall submit disclosures of RPTs transactions on a consolidated basis, in the format specified in the relevant accounting standards for annual results to the stock exchanges and publish the same on its website within 30 days from the date of publication of its standalone and consolidated financial results for the half year.</li> 
	<li style="text-align:justify">Annual Report shall include disclosures in compliance with the Accounting Standard on “Related Party Disclosures”.</li> 
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Transfer Pricing effect on RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">RPTs are not governed by the conditions/ requirement specified by the Companies Act, 2013 or the SEBI regulations but also by Transfer Pricing regulations under the Income Tax Act, 1961 to prevent shifting out of profits from India by manipulating prices charged international transactions between Related Parties/ Associate Enterprises which results in erosion of tax base of India.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">In 2012 concept of Specified Domestic Transactions was introduced in Transfer Pricing Regulations to prevent tax mitigation in transactions entered into between domestic companies as well. So the basic purpose of Transfer Pricing regulation is to keep a check that International as well as Specified Domestic Transactions between Related Parties/ Associated Enterprises are done on an arm’s length basis and to curb tax arbitrage by shifting the profits within the group and reducing the overall tax burden of a group or a Company.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>International Transaction between two or more Associated Enterprises shall include:</u></p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">purchase, sale, transfer, lease or use of tangible property including building, transportation vehicle, machinery, equipment, tools, plant, furniture, commodity or any other article, product or thing;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">purchase, sale, transfer, lease or use of intangible property including the transfer of ownership or the provisions of use of rights regarding land use, copyrights, patents, trademarks, licences, franchises, customer list, marketing channel, brand, commercial secret, know-how, industrial property right, exterior design or practical and new design or any other business or commercial rights of similar nature;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">capital financing including any type of long-term or short-term borrowing, lending or guarantee, purchase or sale of marketable securities or any type of advance, payments or deferred payment or receivable or any other debt arising during the course of business;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">provision of services including provision of market research, market development, marketing management, administration, technical service, repairs, design, consultation, agency, scientific research, legal or accounting service;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">a transaction of business restructuring or reorganization, entered into by an enterprise with Associated Enterprise, irrespective of the fact that it has bearing on the profit, income, losses or assets of such enterprises at the time of the transaction or at any future date.</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Specified domestic transaction in case of an assessee shall mean any of the following transactions, not being an International Transaction:</u></p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">any transaction referred to in Section 80A of the Income Tax Act, 1961;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any transfer of goods or services referred to in Section 80IA(8) of the Income Tax Act, 1961;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any business transacted between the assessee and the other person as referred to in Section 80IA(10) of the Income Tax Act, 1961;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any transaction referred to in any other Section under Chapter VI-A or Section 10AA of the Income Tax Act, 1961, to which provisions of Sections 80IA(8) or 80IA(10) are applicable; or</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">any business transacted between the persons referred to in Section 115BAB(4) of the Income Tax Act, 1961</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">and where the aggregate of such transactions entered into by the assessee in the previous year exceeds a sum of INR 20 crore.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Associated Enterprise, in relation to another enterprise, means an enterprise:</u></p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">which participates, directly or indirectly, or through one or more intermediaries, in the management or control or capital of the other enterprise; or</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">in respect of which one or more persons who participate, directly or indirectly, or through one or more intermediaries, in its management or control or capital, are the same persons who participate directly or indirectly, or through one or more intermediaries, in the management or control or capital of the other enterprise.</li>	
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">Further, Section 92A(2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961prescribes the criteria for considering two enterprises as deemed to be Associated Enterprises.</p>

<ul>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Determination of Transfer Price should always be done at arm’s length price. Arm’s length price shall mean a price at which an entity shall transfer or sell goods or services to its associated enterprise at the same price at which it would have transferred or sold goods or services to any unrelated or unassociated independent enterprise.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		There are various methods, being the most appropriate method, for computation of arm’s length price as per Income Tax Act, 1961 which are as follows:
		<ol type="i">
			<li style="text-align:justify">comparable uncontrolled price method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">resale price method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">cost plus method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">profit split method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">transactional net margin method;</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">such other method as may be prescribed by the Board.</li>
		</ol>
		<p style="text-align:justify">The most appropriate method shall be applied for determination of arm’s length price in the manner as may be prescribed under the Income Tax Act or the Finance Act.</p>
		<p style="text-align:justify">Where more than one price is determined by the most appropriate method, the arm’s length price shall be taken to be the arithmetical mean of such prices. However, if the variation between the arm’s length price so determined and price at which the International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction has actually been undertaken does not exceed 3%, the price at which the International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction has actually been undertaken shall be deemed to be the arm’s length price.</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Company shall maintain all records, information or document with respect to International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction as may be prescribed under the Income Tax Act, 1961. Failure to maintain all records, information or document shall attract a penalty of 2% of the total sum of transaction involved and failure to furnish the information or any document shall attract a penalty of INR 500/-.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Every Company who has entered into an International Transaction or Specified Domestic Transaction during the previous year shall obtain a report in Form 3CEB from an accountant and furnish such report on or before 30th November of the relevant Assessment Year.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Implication of Goods and Services Tax (GST) on RPTs:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Transactions between Related Persons for inadequate or no consideration shall be considered as supply and chargeable to GST under Schedule I of the GST Act. It is considered as supply only if such transaction happens in course or furtherance of business.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Related Person under GST:</u></p>
<ul type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Officer/ Director of one business is the Officer/ Director of another business;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Legally recognized partners in business;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Employer and Employee;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Person who directly or indirectly owns, controls or holds 25% or more of the outstanding voting stocks or shares or both;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">one of them directly or indirectly controls the other;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">both of them are directly or indirectly controlled by a third person;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">together they directly or indirectly control a third person; or</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">they are members of the same family;</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify">The term person includes legal person as well.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Further, persons who are associated in the business of one another in that one is the sole agent or sole distributor or sole concessionaire, howsoever described, of the other, shall be deemed to be related.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><u>Valuation:</u></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">The Government has notified various valuation rules for determining the value of supply in absence of consideration or in case of inadequate consideration for having a base for charging GST. However, if the buyer is eligible for full input tax credit, then the value of invoice will be considered as the value of transaction without any dispute, as it will be tax neutral for the GST Department and will have no impact of value being increased or decreased.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Conclusion:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">RPTs are governed and regulated by various set of statutes impacting corporate governance as well as taxation of a Company and therefore should be undertaken with utmost care, as RPTs, carry an inherent risk of transaction being done to favour or profit the Related Party which could result in causing harm to the interests of the Company’s shareholders. It does not only harm the interests of the shareholders but also of the other stakeholders like government, statutory authorities, banks, financial institutions, etc.</p>

    <p style="text-align:justify"><strong>What is Audit?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Audit</strong> in general means a post-mortem exercise of a project or operations or a particular job/ assignment which helps (i) in finding/ evaluating faults which were made during the currency of a project/ operation/ assignment or in the systems/ processes followed for such project/ operation/ assignment and; (ii) to identify the weaknesses or right/ wrong and to improve on it for the future, so as to minimize future losses and risks.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Audit can be of anything, financial records, books of accounts, processes/ systems, compliances but audit is more often known for verification of books of accounts, financial records & controls of a person. <strong>Audit</strong> of financial records/ books of accounts means examination and verification by an independent person without bias, of the financial records/ books of accounts, its authenticity and to identify or unearth frauds or mal-intentions happening in an organization or against the organization, so as to protect the interest of all its stakeholders.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">In this article we have covered types of audits of financial records or operations applicable to organizations under the Companies Act, 2013 & Limited Liability Partnership Act, 2008.</p>

<h4 style="text-align:justify">A. STATUTORY AUDIT</h4>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>I. <u>Under the Companies Act, 2013:</u></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Every Company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2013 is required to get its books of account/ financial records audited by the Statutory Auditor as per the provisions of the sections and rules covered under the Chapter X - Audit & Auditors of the Companies Act, 2013.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Who can be appointed as a Statutory Auditor(s):</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">An independent person who is an Chartered Accountant can only be appointed as a Statutory Auditor of the Company. In case of firm including Limited Liability Partnership (LLP), where majority of partners practising in India are qualified for appointment, such firm can be appointed as the Statutory Auditor in its name.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">In case of firms including LLP appointed as a Statutory Auditor, only the partners who are Chartered Accountants shall be authorised to act and sign on behalf of the firm.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Further, a person shall satisfy all the criteria prescribed under Section 141 of the Companies Act, 2013 for being appointed as a Statutory Auditor and shall vacate his office if he incurs any disqualification stated in the aforesaid section.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Appointment of Statutory Auditor:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>(i) First Statutory Auditor after incorporation of the Company:</strong></p>
<ol type="a">
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		<u>For Company (other than the Government Company or any other Company owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, fully or partially, by the Central or State Government(s)):</u>
		<p>The first Statutory Auditor after the incorporation of the Company shall be appointed by the Board of Directors within 30 (Thirty) days of the incorporation and in case of failure of the Board of Directors to appoint a Statutory Auditor within the said time period, the Board of Directors shall call upon an Extra-Ordinary General Meeting of the Company for appointing a Statutory Auditor. The first Statutory Auditor shall hold office till the conclusion of the first Annual General Meeting (AGM) of the Company.</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		<u>For Government Company or any other Company owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, fully or partially, by the Central or State Government(s):</u>
		<p>The first Statutory Auditor shall be appointed by the Comptroller and Auditor-General (CAG) of India within 60 (Sixty) days from the incorporation of the Company. In case the CAG does not appoint the first Statutory Auditor within the said time period, the Board of Directors of the Company shall appoint such Statutory Auditor within next 30 (Thirty) days and in case of failure of the Board of Directors, an Extra-Ordinary General Meeting shall be called for appointment a Statutory Auditor within next 60 (Sixty) days. The first Statutory Auditor shall hold office till the conclusion of the first AGM of the Company.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>(ii) Appointment of Statutory Auditor after first appointment:</strong></p>
<ol type="a">
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		<u>For Company (other than the Government Company or any other Company owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, fully or partially, by the Central or State Government(s)):</u>
		<p>Statutory Auditor, after the first appointment post incorporation, shall be appointed at the first* AGM of the company to hold office from the conclusion of the said AGM till the conclusion of its 6<sup>th</sup> AGM.</p>
		<p><em><u>Explanation:</u> First AGM shall mean the AGM in which a person was appointed as a Statutory Auditor. So after the completion of 5 years, if the Statutory Auditor is appointed in the 6th AGM then such 6th AGM shall be considered as the first AGM for that term.</em></p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		<u>For Government Company or any other Company owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, fully or partially, by the Central or State Government(s):</u>
		<p>Statutory Auditor, after the first appointment post incorporation, shall be appointed by the CAG in respect of a financial year, within a period of 180 (One Hundred & Eighty) days from the commencement of the financial year and such Statutory Auditor shall hold office till the conclusion of the ensuing AGM.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>(iii) Appointment in Casual Vacancy:</strong></p>
<ol type="a">
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		<u>For Company (other than the Government Company or any other Company owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, fully or partially, by the Central or State Government(s)):</u>
		<p>Any casual vacancy arising in the office of the Statutory Auditor shall be filled by the Board of Directors within 30 (Thirty) days of casual vacancy but if such casual vacancy is as a result of the resignation of the existing Statutory Auditor, such appointment in casual vacancy shall also be approved by the Company at a General Meeting convened within 3 (Three) months of the recommendation of the Board of Directors and Statutory Auditor appointed in casual vacancy shall hold office till the conclusion of the next AGM.</p>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		<u>For Government Company or any other Company owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, fully or partially, by the Central or State Government(s):</u>
		<p>Casual Vacancy shall be filled by the CAG within 30 (Thirty) days and if the CAG does not fill the casual vacancy within the said period, the Board of Directors shall fill the casual vacancy within next 30 (Thirty) days.</p>
	</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong><em>Note:	Any appointment of Statutory Auditor including in Casual Vacancy shall be made only after consultation of the Audit Committee, where it is required to be constituted.</em></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Intimation of appointment of Statutory Auditor shall be given to the Registrar of Companies (ROC) in e-form <strong>ADT-1</strong> within 30 (Thirty) days of its appointment.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Rotation of Statutory Auditors:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Following Companies shall not appoint or re-appoint (a) an individual as Statutory Auditor for more than one term of 5 (Five) consecutive years; and (b) an audit firm as Statutory Auditor for more than two terms of 5 (Five) consecutive years.</p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Listed Companies</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">All Unlisted Public Companies having paid-up share capital of INR 10 crore or more</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">All Private Companies having paid-up share capital of INR 50 crore or more</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">All Companies having paid-up share capital below the threshold limit mentioned in (ii) & (iii) above but having public borrowings from financial institutions, banks or public deposits of INR 50 crores or more.</li>	
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">An individual or an audit firm which has completed its respective term as stated above shall not be eligible for re-appointment as Statutory Auditor in the same Company for 5 (Five) years from the completion of such term. Further, the rotation of Statutory Auditors shall be made in accordance with the Rules made under Section 139(2) of the Companies Act, 2013.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>What should be reported in the Audit Report by the Statutory Auditor?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">The Statutory Auditor shall prepare a report for the members of the Company on the books of accounts examined by him and on financial statements after taking into consideration-</p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">the provisions of the Companies Act, 2013 including Rules made thereunder;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">the Accounting and Auditing Standards and matters prescribed by the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) and National Financial Reporting Authority (NFRA);</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">frauds involving amounts as prescribed in the Section 143(12) of the Companies Act, 2013 committed in the Company by the officer/ employees; and</li>	
	<li style="text-align:justify">matters as may be prescribed in the Companies (Auditor’s Report) Order as may be issued by the Central Government from time to time and put his comments/ observations/ adverse remarks/ qualifications/ reservation with explanation.</li>	
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>II. <u>Under the Limited Liability Partnership Act, 2008:</u></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Not all Limited Liability Partnerships (LLPs) are required to get their books of accounts audited but only those LLPs whose turnover in any financial year exceeds INR 40 (Forty) lakhs or whose contribution exceeds INR 25 (Twenty-Five) lakhs are required to get their books of accounts audited in accordance with the LLP Rules.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Who can be appointed as a Statutory Auditor?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Like Companies, only a Chartered Accountant in practice can be appointed as the Statutory Auditor of LLP.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Appointment of Statutory Auditor:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Designated Partners of LLP shall appoint Statutory Auditor(s) in the following manner:</p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify"><u>For the first financial year:</u> Any time during the first financial year but before the end of the first financial year</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify"><u>Other than first financial year:</u> At least 30 (Thirty) days prior to the end of the each financial year</li>	
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify">If Designated Partners fail to appoint the Statutory Auditor as above, the Partners, if any of the LLP shall appoint the Statutory Auditor in the above manner.</p>

<h4 style="text-align:justify">B. INTERNAL AUDIT</h4>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>What is an internal Audit?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">An internal audit is the examination of the functions and activities of the Company by an Internal Person as compared to by an Independent Person doing the Statutory Audit. It evaluates effectiveness of the Company’s accounting process, financial control, governance and risk management so as to identify frauds, and manipulation/ misuse of funds/ records of the Company and reporting of risks associated to the operations or internal processes (financial or non-financial) of the Company to the Management of the Company.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Applicability of Internal Audit:</strong></p>
<ol type="a">
	<li style="text-align:justify">Every Listed Company;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Every Unlisted Company which fulfils any of the following conditions: 
		<ol type="i">
			<li style="text-align:justify">having paid-up share capital of INR 50 (Fifty) crore or more during the preceding financial year; or</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">having turnover of INR 200 (Two Hundred) crore or more any time during the preceding financial year; or</li>	
			<li style="text-align:justify">having outstanding loans or borrowings from banks or public financial institutions exceeding INR (One Hundred) crore or more at any time during the preceding financial year; or</li>	
			<li style="text-align:justify">having outstanding deposits of INR 25 (Twenty-Five) crore or more at any time during the preceding financial year.</li>	
		</ol>
	</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">
		Every Private company which fulfils any of the following conditions:
		<ol type="i">
			<li style="text-align:justify">having turnover of INR 200 (Two Hundred) crore or more during the preceding financial year; or</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">having outstanding loans or borrowings from banks or public financial institutions exceeding INR 100 (One Hundred) crore or more at any point of time during the preceding financial year.</li>
		</ol>
	</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Who can be an Internal Auditor?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">As per Section 138 of the Companies Act, 2013, a Chartered Accountant or a Cost Accountant can be appointed as an Internal Auditor of the Company. An Internal Auditor can be an Employee of the Company as well.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Appointment of Internal Auditor</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">The internal Auditor of the company is required to be appointed by the Board of Director of the Company and with the due consent of the Internal Auditor.</p>

<h4 style="text-align:justify">C. COST RECORDS AUDIT</h4>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong><u>What is Cost Audit?</u></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">As the name suggests, Cost Audit is the audit of the cost records of the company, it is conducted in addition to the financial audit. The Cost and Works Accountants of India (ICWA) actually defines a cost audit as a system that reviews and examines cost accounting records, which means examination of the accuracy of the cost records and that all cost accounting principal were adhered reflecting the true picture of the organization financial status.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong><u>Applicability of Cost Audit</u></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Cost Audit is applicable to the Companies engaged in production of such goods and providing of such services as prescribed under <strong>Rule 3 of the Companies (Cost Records and Audit) Rules, 2014:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Every Company specified in item (A) of Rule 3:</strong> The overall annual turnover of the company from all its product and services, falling under the Regulated Sectors, during the immediately preceding financial year is <strong>INR 50 (Fifty) crore or more</strong> and the aggregate turnover of the individual product or products or services for which cost records are required to be maintained under Rule 3 is <strong>INR 25 (Twenty-Five) crore or more.</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Every Company specified in item (B) of Rule 3:</strong>  The overall annual turnover of the company from all its products and services, falling under the Non-Regulated Sectors, during the immediately preceding financial year is <strong>INR 100 (One Hundred) crore or more</strong> and the aggregate turnover of the individual product or products or service for which cost records are required to be maintained under Rule 3 is <strong>INR 35 (Thirty-Five) crore or more.</strong></p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Note:</strong> The above Requirement of Cost Audit shall not apply to the Companies-</p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">whose revenue from exports, in foreign exchange, exceeds seventy five per cent of its total revenue;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">which is operating from a Special Economic Zone;</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">which is engaged in generation of electricity for captive consumption through Captive Generating Plant. (For this purpose, the term "Captive Generating Plant" shall have the same meaning as assigned in rule 3 of the Electricity Rules, 2005.)</li>
</ol>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Who can be appointed as a Cost Auditor?</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">A Cost Accountant as defined under the Section 2(1)(b) of the Costs and Works Accountants Act, 1959 and who holds a valid certificate of practice under Section 6(1) of the Costs and Works Accountants Act, 1959 shall be appointed as a Cost Auditor of the Company.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Appointment of Cost Auditor:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">The appointment of the Cost auditor for a financial year shall be made within 180 (One Hundred and Eighty) days from the commencement of each such financial year, by the Board of Directors of the Company.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">However, the Statutory Auditor of the Company cannot be appointed as the Cost Auditor of the Company.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Intimation of appointment of a Cost Auditor shall be made to the Central Government in e-form CRA-2 within 30 (Thirty) days of the Board Meeting in which such appointment is made or within a period of 180 (One Hundred and Eighty) days of the commencement of the financial year, whichever is earlier and such Cost Auditor shall hold office till the expiry of 180 (One Hundred and Eighty) days from the closure of the financial year or till he submits the Cost Audit Report for the financial year for which he was appointed.</p>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>Other requirements with respect to Cost Audit:</strong></p>
<ol type="i">
	<li style="text-align:justify">The Cost Auditor is required to comply with the Cost Auditing Standards i.e. such standards as are issued by the Institute of Cost Accountants of India, constituted under the Cost and Works Accountants Act, 1959, with the approval of the Central Government and the provisions related to the Cost Audit prescribed under the Companies Act, 2013.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">The qualifications, disqualifications, rights, duties and obligations applicable to Statutory Auditor shall, so far as may be applicable, apply to a cost auditor.</li>
	<li style="text-align:justify">Cost Auditor shall submit its report along with his observations/ remarks/ qualifications/ reservations/ suggestions in Form CRA-3 within a period of 180 (One Hundred and Eighty) days from the closure of the financial year to which the report relates. Within 30 (Thirty) days of the receipt of the Cost Audit Report, the Company shall file the report in e-form CRA-4 in Extensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL) with the Central Government.</li>
</ol>

The payment must be approved by the Board of Directors.</p>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>II. Significance of Dividend to the Corporate</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Company that pays out a dividend attracts investors and creates demand for their stock.</li>
<li>Investors see a dividend payment as a sign of a company's strength and a sign that management has positive expectations for future earnings, which again makes the stock more attractive.</li>
<li>Paying dividends sends a clear, powerful message about a company's future prospects and performance, and its willingness and ability to pay steady dividend over the period of time.</li>
<li>Evaluation of stocks using dividend is often a more reliable equity evaluation measure than many other more commonly used metrics such as price-to-earnings, or P/E ratio.</li>
<li>A company consistently increasing its dividend payments gives clear indication that the company is steadily generating profits and is less likely to have its basic financial health threatened by the temporary market or economic downturns.</li>
<li>Studies have historically shown that dividend-paying stocks outperform non-dividend-paying stocks during bear market period. While an overall downmarket generally drags down stocks across the board, dividend-paying stocks usually suffer significantly less decline in value than non-dividend-paying stocks.</li>
<li>Dividend stocks have proved to be less volatile. As per a Merrill Lynch study, stocks with a history of steadily increasing dividends outperformed non-dividend paying stocks from 1990 to 2018 with less volatility.</li>
<li>Dividend yields outpace inflation. It reduces the effect of inflation on investment returnsand represents an actual gain in purchasing power for the investor.</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>III.	Dividend-Paying Methods:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align:justify">Company can pay dividend by adopting dividend policies as outlined below:</p>
<ul>
	<li>
		Residual Dividend Policy:<br>
		<p>Under this method company relies on internally generated equity to finance any new projects. As a result, dividend payments can come out of the residual or leftover equity only after all project capital requirements are met.</p>
		<p>The benefits to this method is that it allows a company to use their retained earnings or residual income to invest back into the company, or into other profitable projects before returning funds back to shareholders in the form of dividend.</p>
		<p>One of the drawbacks of this method that it can lead to inconsistent and periodic dividend payouts resulting in volatility in the company's stock price.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
		Stable Dividend Policy:<br>
		<p>Under this policy, companies consistently pay a dividend each year regardless of earning fluctuations. The dividend payout amount is typically determined through forecasting long-term earnings and calculating a percentage of earnings to be paid out.</p>
		<p>Under this policy, companies may create a target payout ratio, which is a percentage of earnings that is to be paid to shareholders in the long-term.</p>
		<p>The company may choose a cyclical policy that sets dividends at a fixed fraction of quarterly earnings, or it may choose a stable policy whereby quarterly dividends are set at a fraction of yearly earnings. In either case, the aim of the stability policy is to reduce uncertainty for investors and to provide them stable income.</p>
	</li>
	<li>
		HybridDividend Policy:<br>
		<p>This policy is combination of residual and stable dividend policies. The hybrid is a popular approachfor companies that pay dividends. Companies that use the hybrid approach establish a set dividend, which represents a relatively small portion of yearly income and can be easily maintained. In addition to the set dividend, companies can offer an extra dividend paid only when income exceeds certain benchmarks.</p>
	</li>
</ul>

<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>IV. Types of Dividends:</strong></p>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Special Dividend:</strong> This type of dividend is paid on common stock. It is issued under a particular circumstancewhen company has accumulated substantial profits over several years. Mostly such profits are looked at as excess cash that does not need to be used at the given moment or in the immediate future.</li>
	<li><strong>Preferred Dividend:</strong> This type of dividend is issued to preferred stock ownersand usually accrues a fixed amount that is paid quarterly. Also, this kind of dividend is earned on shares that function more likely bonds.</li>
	<li><strong>Cash Dividend:</strong> It is easy and payment can made through cash directly from the company to the account of the shareholder. The payment is usually made electronically but sometime it is also extended through cheque. The dividend can be classified in two types namely (i) Interim Dividend and (ii) Final Dividend.
		<p>Generally, a Company opts to pay Dividend out of profits at the end of the financial year which is termed as Final Dividend and the same is declared in Annual General Meeting (AGM). However, the Company may also choose to declare Dividend between two AGMs depending on the amount of profits earned and the same is termed as Interim Dividend.</p>
		<p>Dividend can be either Equity Dividend which is paid to equity shareholders of the Company or Preference Dividend which is paid to preference shareholders of the Company. Preference shareholders are preferred above equity shareholders for payment of Dividend, when declared and paid.</p>
	</li>
</ul>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>V. Impact of Dividend on Share Price:</strong></p>
<p>It must be noted that paying dividends to the shareholders may not influence the overall value of business. Further, when company declares a dividend, its share prices undergo significant increased governed by market activities. Investors are more likely to pay a premium in the hope of earning dividends. However, the share prices start to decline by a similar proportion once the date of dividend eligibility expires. Such a fall usually occurs when new investors are not deemed eligible to receive dividend and hence reluctant when it comes to paying the associated premium. </p>
<p>Similarly, if the market is anticipated to remain optimistic until an ex-dividend date, the increase in stock’s value may be higher than the dividend offered. Irrespective of reductions, such an occurrence often leads to an increase in the overall value of the company’s stock.  The amount paid out in dividends no longer belongs to the company, and this is reflected by a reduction in the company's market cap,instead, it belongs to the individual shareholders. For those purchasing shares after the ex-dividend date, they no longer have a claim to the dividend, so the exchange adjusts the price downward to reflect this fact. </p>
<p style="text-align:justify"><strong>VI. Dividend as per Companies Act, 2013:</strong></p>
<ul>
	<li>Interim Dividend:
		<ol type="i">	
			<li style="text-align:justify">Interim Dividend can be declared out of:
				<ol type="a">
					<li style="text-align:justify">The Surplus in the Profit and Loss Account; and/ or</li>
					<li style="text-align:justify">Out of the profits of the financial year for which such interim Dividend is sought to be declared; or</li>
					<li style="text-align:justify">Out of profits generated in the financial year till the quarter preceding the date of declaration of the interim Dividend.</li>
				</ol>
			</li>
			<li style="text-align:justify">Before declaration of Interim Dividend, Board of Directors should be satisfied that the financial position of the company justifies and supports the declaration of such Dividend.</li> 			<li style="text-align:justify">Where a company has issued equity shares with differential rights as to Dividend, Interim Dividend may, at the option of the Board, be declared on all or any one or more of the classes of such shares in accordance with the terms of issue.</li> 			<li style="text-align:justify">In case Interim Dividend is declared on only one class of equity shares, the Board shall ensure that the profit as shown in the financial results is adequate to meet the Dividend that would have to be paid on the other classes of equity shares in accordance with the terms of issue.</li> 		</ol> 	</li> 	 	<li> 		Final Dividend:  		<ol type="i"> 			<li style="text-align:justify">Final Dividend can be declared out of: 				<ol type="a"> 					<li style="text-align:justify">The profits of the Company for that year arrived at after providing for depreciation in accordance with the provisions of Schedule II of the Companies Act, 2013; or</li> 					<li style="text-align:justify">The undistributed profits of the Company for any previous financial year or years arrived at after providing for depreciation in accordance with the provisions of Schedule II;or</li> 					<li style="text-align:justify">Botha & b above</li> 					<li style="text-align:justify">Dividend may also be declared out of money provided by the Central Government or a State Government in pursuance of a guarantee given by such Government for this purpose.</li> 				</ol> 			</li> 			 			<li style="text-align:justify"> 				Unrealized gains, notional gains or revaluation of assets and any change in carrying amount of asset or liability at fair value shall be excluded from computation of profits as above. 			</li> 			<li style="text-align:justify"> 				Company shall not declare Dividend unless carried over previous losses and depreciation are set off against profit of the Company for the current year. 			</li> 			<li style="text-align:justify"> 				Company shall transfer such appropriate percentage of profits,at the rate the Company deems fit at its discretion, to the reserves of the Company before declaration of Dividend and Dividend shall be declared from the free reserves only. 			</li> 		</ol> 	</li> 	 	<li> 		<strong>Dividend in case of Inadequate Profits:</strong> If the Company is not having adequate profits for the financial year for which the Dividend is declaredor there are no profits, then the company may declare Dividend out of Free Reserves, subject to following conditions: 		<ol type="i"> 			<li style="text-align:justify"> 				Rate of Dividend shall not exceed average rate of Dividend declared in immediately preceding 3 financial years.
